sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/sysinv/db/sqlalchem.message: What was the purpose of this? Will it impact upgrades?

Sorry I meant to add a comment. 

This is necessary for our unit tests. Our unit tests use SQLite and the schema wasn't being updated by the existing code. Without this change we could only add service parameters in the 'identity' service. 

Prior to this the SQLite schema looked like this: 
CREATE TABLE service_parameter (created_at DATETIME, updated_at DATETIME, deleted_at DATETIME, id INTEGER NOT NULL, uuid VARCHAR(36), section VARCHAR(255), name VARCHAR(255), value VARCHAR(255), PRIMARY KEY (id), UNIQUE (uuid), CHECK (service IN (\'identity\')))

I tested with the change and the schema produced on a clean install does not change. This won't impact upgrades as this predates stx R1.

I'm a little bit tempted to ask you to just put these in snap-overlay/bin.

MicroStack uses both a "wrapper" convention and a "put things in snap-overlay/bin" convention. The snap-wrappers are a little bit easier to discover, while the snap-overlay makes for a smaller snapcraft.yaml file, because we handle everything there in one step.

Thinking about it further ... I think that this is fine. Someday, we need to pick a convention and stick to it, but for now, both are equally okay.

patrole_tempest_plugin/tests/api/network.message:
I'd consider doing it this way:

    with self.resore_manager_credentials:
        # Import neutron-tempest-plugin clients
        if cls.is_neutron_tempest_plugin_available():
            from neutron_tempest_plugin.api import clients
            neutron_tempest_manager = clients.Manager(manager.credentials)
            cls.ntp_client = neutron_tempest_manager.network_client

Where self.resore_manager_credentials implements the contextmanager pattern:

@contextmanager
def restore_manager_credentials():
    manager_creds = copy.deepcopy(manager.credentials)
    try:
        yield
    finally:
        manager.credentials = manager_creds

That way you also cover every single attribute, not just tenant_id and user_id.

Also I'm curious why the creds are lost in the first place when you call clients.Manager.

Finally consider only doing this if dynamic credentials = False is set (and you can add that condition inside the contextmanager function itself).

I'm not sure at which point tempest.lib modifies this object (tempest.lib seems to be the root cause, not neutron-tempest-plugin) but I think the better workaround here is much simpler:

            # Import neutron-tempest-plugin clients
            if cls.is_neutron_tempest_plugin_available():
                from neutron_tempest_plugin.api import clients
                neutron_tempest_manager = clients.Manager(copy.deepcopy(manager.credentials))

The manager object won't be modified if you simply pass in a new manager.credentials object, thereby avoiding the need to restore anything and is a pretty trivial change.
thanks for the review. I agree this is much cleaner and intuitive approach. I will push a new PS.

I do not think clients.Manager modifies the credential. is something buggy in Tempest side. 

Can you please log the bug and add failure details so what we can debug the real root cause. Doing this workaround will hide the real issue and we will forget to debug that.

Looks like the "credentials.user_id" and "credentials.tenant_id" is being dropped when self.clear_auth() is being called here: https://github.com/openstack/tempest/blob/master/tempest/lib/auth.py#L251

Any suggestions on how this can be fixed in Tempest?

Thanks for the review and I agree that the real root cause should be investigated. I dug into the Tempest code and can't figure out where 'user_id' and 'tenant_id' is being set to None. I created this bug https://bugs.launchpad.net/tempest/+bug/1846410 and could use some help finding the root cause in Tempest.
the bug should be in the neutron tempest plugin.  The question is should we protect tempest from this and correct this or just correct this in someone else plugin?

os_brick/initiator/connectors/nvmeof.py.message:
When we use -q flag when connecting (line 179) we overwrite what is in /etc/nvme/hostnqn
Because of that we should store host nqn used while connecting (if it was used) and check here if such host nqn was stored at connection time. If yes then use the stored one otherwise use one present in /etc/nvme/hostnqn

I guess it means that host_nqn value passed to connect_volume() would have to be stored in a DB, because get_connector_properties() is a static method, which creates a new NVMeOFConnector object. Did I understand you correctly?

> I guess it means that host_nqn value passed to connect_volume()
 > would have to be stored in a DB, because get_connector_properties()
 > is a static method, which creates a new NVMeOFConnector object. Did
 > I understand you correctly?

After taking a closer look at this approach, I think that storing host nqn in a DB doesn't fit os-brick design. os-brick is a small, stateless module and its implementation should be kept as simple as possible.

The idea behind my patch, was to retrieve host NQN value from a default location, in a similar fashion as it's done for IQN in iSCSI connector.

If user chooses to ignore the default value and overwrite it, I don't think it's os-brick responsibility to keep track of it.

I'd appreciate any additional feedback on this.

i am not sure that is compatible with 
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/amd-sev-libvirt-support.html
or rather i do not think its inline with the direction we had in mind for supporting mktme in the future.

our current intention is to use 
hw:mem_encryption to request sev or mktme.

if you just set hw:mem_encryption=true it will request 1 mem encryption context which corraltates with 1 mktme key.

to specifically select sev or mktme a trait request would be used instead of the propsed mem_enc_sec:type.

not that for sev we had planned to use the "HW:" namespace not that intoduce a new namespace which is one of the deltas between what has already been agreed for sev vs what this spec proposes.

At present we are not planning to allow the user to select an encrption algorithim or key type. i am not sure if this is something we should expose as configuarable paramaters.
if we do we need to be able to schdule on the encryption algortioms and key types.

One of the key feature of MKTME is key can be defined and generated with in the CPU or the key can be provided by the user(through KMS). It is same used case on Openstack context, but providing user a choice for key usage for encryption.

I agree with Sean here regarding mem_enc_sec.  Please read the SEV spec he links to understand the agreed architecture.  We specifically designed it to allow expansion to MKTME in the future whilst ensuring a user-friendly interface and allowing clouds to mix and match SEV and MKTME.

Regarding mem_enc_secpolicy:key-type - when would "cpu" be selected vs. "user"?  Are they for different use cases in the OpenStack cloud context?

I wasn't aware of  hw:mem_encryption prefix during this write up. But I agree with the current design and will change the blueprint accordingly.
But MKTME requires kind of policy configuration, because with this user can configure with CPU generated key or user defined key. And also for now we can remove encryption algorithm. But wanted to suggest all the parameters associated with the policy.

I'm not sure if we should support shared keys.

It would be incorrect to allow sharing between different tenants, as such i can only see this as useful if and only if
we combined it with server affinity groupe.

I'm equally uncertain about this.  If there is a use case for key sharing in the OpenStack context, this spec should explain it.

that is not how placement works.

the placement inventory would be created by the compute manager as part of update_provider_tree then when scheduling a instance to a host an allocation is claimed in placement before we spawn an instance on the host.

the nova compute agent does not need to update the placement on every instance spawn because we claim the allocation in the scheduler before we select the host. if we can claim the allocation we select one of the alternate host and repeat until we no longer have any alternates or have successfully claimed an allocation candidate in placement.

Sorry for not noticing this before. We probably need to change to logic here for a bit, specially with the 'copy-image' coming into the picture. This logic has couple of major risks:

1) If the system wide hashing algo changes between the original creation of the image and copying it we will be overwriting the multihash from the metadata. There is no way for the enduser to know that the image is actually the same image they got originally as the hash (and algorithm) has changed during the image lifetime. The immutability promise has always been the top most priority for Glance and we should address it here too.

There might be protection for this already in the codepath. (I'm not sure how the image will behave if internally try to change the values.) But that will just cause that the second concern of mine is not valid and all cases of this first one will fail without way of recovering from it.

2) If there is corruption of the data between the first and last _upload_to_store, we silently ignore it and just write the last hash to the image metadata.

Simple ways to address these risks:
1) If the image is active and has multihash values in it we use the hashing algo from the image instead of the value in the config file.
2) If the image has os_hash_value we will just compare the checksum we calculated instead of blindly updating it. Should these two not match we will need to raise an exception and log it (error) to indicate that there is some serious issues in our datapath.

NOTE: Our tasks revert logic needs to take this into account. If we are reverting the image back to queued without any locations left, we need to make sure we clean up the multihash metadata as well. (This might be the most difficult part if we indeed do have protections against changing these values in the codepath.)

Good catch and clear explanation :)
I'll modify the method _verify_upload to add these necessary checks. We should be able to keep lines 478 to 483 as if we go through _verify_upload without getting an exception, the hash values are either the same or not yet set on the image.

magnum/drivers/common/templates/kubernet.message: Nit: KUBE_SHA256 looks too similar to KUBE_TAG_SHA256. can we think of a better name? I would prefer it as just SHA256 or DIGEST.
I hear you and I know it's not a perfect name. I would avoid just using SHA256 because it's too blur because the sha256 is only for the k8s image(s). How about k8s_image_sha256 or k8s_image_digest?
Don't we need this in enable-services-minion too?
Good point. But because Magnum will bootstrap master node before worker node, so if the image digest doesn't match, the the cluster will fail when booting master.
It would be useful for nodegroups. We can merge without it. I don't mind.
That's a very good point. I can add it later. Thanks.

doc/source/contributor/index.rst.message: nit: not needed (refs are never needed at the top of a file, you can always use :doc:)

setup.cfg.message: do we still want to support Python 2.x ?
I understand your concern, my thought if I were in that situation would be to create a virtualenv just for sushy-cli, or again a container ready for use that I can distribute wherever I need it.

Good question...

Would it be good to be able to run this cli tool in some older cloud installations...?

I thought the same, but then I also thought that this is a client app, and it's independent from the architecture you use it against, also it has Sushy >= 3.0.0 in the requirements, which is Python 3 only.
Supposedly you can even install it in a container, but in any case in any modern distro you can find Python 3 now.
In the end, I don't think we need Python 2 support.

Right... The only scenario that might cause nuisances I can think of if you have older OpenStack under cloud with sushy <3.0.0 installed globally, and you want to hack on your BMC from there.

With that scenario, the user will probably have to have two sushy versions just for sake of CLI... But may be it's not that important use-case...?
